An intern reused an RSA prime to secure multiple messages. Can you exploit the repeated prime flaw to recover the secret from 4371472684785967888777949702676962162780285458954056818510958900740714835389110108800181192616951491504808122860963468920175409316646325455695478911307456?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=4667835376404267134845358757342732436284569845899929190383057881301593805741999888967829394869864213957007905824030690244498710320912792916007900530676441, e=3857165760589241929422481243977231262664802471204705818454533754590474013238900586584983574538509555979388694250719146932763049415070649550484788996702609

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{4qnsujix}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 4371472684785967888777949702676962162780285458954056818510958900740714835389110108800181192616951491504808122860963468920175409316646325455695478911307456
vulnerability: repeated primes
hint: The RSA modulus n is a perfect square. This often indicates a repeated prime usage vulnerability.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=4667835376404267134845358757342732436284569845899929190383057881301593805741999888967829394869864213957007905824030690244498710320912792916007900530676441, e=3857165760589241929422481243977231262664802471204705818454533754590474013238900586584983574538509555979388694250719146932763049415070649550484788996702609
extra_info: p=68321558650284517164958427125444220639515424312937945018746437695920236128229, q=68321558650284517164958427125444220639515424312937945018746437695920236128229, Ï†(n)=4667835376404267134845358757342732436284569845899929190383057881301593805741863245850528825835534297102757017382751659395872834430875300040616060058419984
subtype: repeated_prime_usage
archetype: rsa
